Perhaps you noticed the similarity of nastoupil and vystoupil to koupil (he bought). We encountered that verb in the **Past 1** skill, whose tips explored how it relates to kupoval (he was buying). The difference has to do with the perfective/imperfective **aspect** and does not fully map to the simple and progressive tenses in English. We will deal with this in more detail later, but as a preview, yes, nastupoval and vystupoval are the corresponding imperfective forms.

##Once, twice, three times

Unlike the cardinal and ordinal numbers we have already encountered, the multiplicative number words do not change their form and stay as listed below:

| Czech  | English
|:--|:--
| jednou | once
| dvakrt | twice
| tikrt| three times
| tyikrt | four times

The formation pattern suggested by tikrt and tyikrt continues to higher values: Take the cardinal number word and attach krt, so we get ptkrt, devatenctkrt, and dvacetkrt. The *n*krt pattern even holds for multi-word compound cardinal numbers above 20, which should get written as a single word with krt attached (dvacetjednakrt, tistaedestptkrt). 

+ V Nmecku jsem byla ticetestkrt. (I have been to Germany thirty-six times.)

To ask how many times in Czech, use kolikrt (note the spelling):

+ Kolikrt jsi tam byl? (How many times have you been there?)

The multiplicatives are often followed with expressions combining the preposition za with the accusative of a time period noun or noun phrase, such as hodinu, den, tden, msc, rok or deset let, and then they express the number of times per time period:

+ Na Slovensko cestujeme jednou nebo dvakrt za rok. (We travel to Slovakia once or twice a year.)

skills.name: Possessive Adjectives
skills.tipsAndNotes:
# Possessive Adjectives

Czech possessive adjectives (PAs) offer an alternative to the genitive when expressing ownership. Unlike the genitive of possession (auto Frantika), PAs go before the noun (Frantikovo auto).

## Restrictions

In standard Czech, the possessor (owner) name must be

+ **singular** (no PA for "people's republic");
+ **animate**, such as a person or something personified, or an animal (no PA for "water's edge");
+ grammatically **masculine or feminine** (no PA from *dve* or *dt*);
+ referring to a **specific** possessor, not a generic or abstract one (no PA for "man's best friend");
+ a **single word** (no PA for "my younger brother's wife"); and
+ a **noun** (no PAs from feminine surnames, which are adjectives, like *Navrtilov*).

Where these restrictions prevent the use of the PAs, Czech uses other types of adjectives or the genitive of possession.

## Formation and Declension

PAs are formed by adding together three pieces: 

`root + suffix + ending`

+ The "root" comes from the owner noun.
+ The "suffix" mostly depends on the owner gender.
+ The "ending" depends on the owned object gender, number, and case.

To find the **root** for masculine owners,

+ take the accusative of the owner noun (this deletes the "e" from the stem if appropriate; see "ddeek" below); and
+ remove the vowel ending 

| Owner | Accusative | Root |
|:--|:--|:--|
| bratr | bratra | bratr |
| mu | mue | mu |
| ddeek | ddeka | ddek |
| tta | ttu | tt |
| soudce | soudce | soudc |

To find the **root** for feminine owners,

+ take the dative of the owner noun (this captures consonant shifts; see "sestra" and "matka" below);
+ remove the vowel ending; and
+ replace the final "c" with "" and "z" with "" 

| Owner | Dative | Root |
|:--|:--|:--|
| ena | en | en |
| ofie | ofii | ofi |
| sestra | seste | sest |
| matka | matce | mat`` |

The **suffix** goes right after the root and is the simplest PA piece, being:

+ "v" for a masculine owner with a singular masculine owned object in the nominative and singular masculine inanimate owned object in the accusative;
+ "ov" for a masculine owner otherwise; and
+ "in" for a feminine owner 

Finally, the **ending** depends on the gender, number, and case of the *owned object*. In the tables below, "-" denotes an empty ending, i.e., nothing.

For singular objects:

| Case | M (an./in.) | F | N |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| N sg. | - | a | o | 
| A sg. | a / - | u | o |
| G sg. | a | y | a |
| L sg. |  |  |  |
| I sg. | m | ou | m |
| D sg. | u |  | u |

Note that the "v" suffix can only go with the empty ending for a masculine owner. Some learners may benefit from figuring out the ending before the suffix.

For plural objects:

| Case | M (an./in.) | F | N |
|:--|:--|:--|:--|
| N pl. | i / y | y | a | 
| A pl. | y | y | a |
| G pl. | ch | ch | ch |
| L pl. | ch | ch | ch |
| I pl. | mi | mi | mi |
| D pl. | m | m | m |

## Examples

Let's try it on translating "I don't know Frantiek's sister." As a hint, our translation will contain *neznm ... sestru*, with the object in accusative.

+ First we get the PA root for a masculine owner (Frantiek) from its accusative form (Frantika) by dropping the final vowel: "Frantik".
+ Next we pick the right suffix. The owner is masculine but the owned object is not M nom. sg. or M in. acc. sg. (which would give an empty ending next), so the suffix is "ov".
+ Finally, from the tables of endings for A sg. and a feminine object, the ending we get "u".
+ The PA becomes "Frantikovu".

Note that the translation likely gets organized as "Frantikovu sestru neznm." because the "not knowing" is more likely to be the key piece of information than who she is.

Our second example deals with the PA-related issue most frequently debated in sentence discussions for this skill: Whose grandfather is it anyway?

+ Oba ddekovy domy jsou v Praze. (Both of my grandfather's houses are in Prague.)

The main tripping hazard here is the "**my** grandfather's houses" translation. How do we know it was my grandfather of all grandfathers? 

We could have said "both Grandpa's houses", using the family title as if it were a proper noun (note the  capitalization). If I said "Grandpa's new house is in Prague." to you (assuming we are not related), you would apply my statement to **my** grandfather. The same  connection makes the "ddeek" automatically apply to the speaker's grandpa. 

If we wanted to explicitly specify whose grandfather we are talking about, we would lose the ability to use a PA (because PAs do not handle multi-word possessors), and end up replacing "oba ddekovy domy" with the rather less idiomatic "oba domy mho ddeka".

Finally, in

+ Vystoupila z otcova auta. (She got out of her father's car.)

the father could also be the narrator's, but it is a good example where "her" father is just as probable.

skills.name: Relative Clauses 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
# Relative clauses 1
In this skill we learn to construct relative subordinate clauses and connect them to the main clause. To do that, we are going to need relative pronouns as the connecting pieces.

##Relative pronoun "kter"
One of the relative pronouns looks and behaves like the interrogatory pronoun "kter". Recall that this pronoun declines like a hard adjective.

As a relative pronoun, **"kter"** does the job of the English relative pronouns "who", "whom", "which", and "that". This Czech pronoun cannot be omitted, and there is no distinction between restrictive (defining) and non-restrictive (non-defining) use. In Czech, relative clauses need to be set off by commas regardless of whether or not they are restrictive. Only context will show their restrictive status.

The structure of the complex sentence with "kter" can be readily appreciated by first identifying the corresponding question using a form of "kter" as an interrogative. Say we want to translate "He married the girl from whom he had been buying milk every morning." (It is easiest to start from an English sentence from which the relative pronoun was not omitted, and with any associated preposition preceding the pronoun rather than pushed to the end.)

The translation will predictably begin

 + Vzal si dvku ...

The question we need asks about the English subordinate clause and uses the key piece from the main clause that the subordinate clause refers to: 

+ From which girl had he been buying milk every morning? 

We get:

+ U kter dvky kad rno kupoval mlko? ("U" is better than "od" here.)

 Lets delete the piece of the main clause from the question:

 + u kter [dvky] kad rno kupoval mlko

 and stitch it together, using the required comma:

+ Vzal si dvku, u kter kad rno kupoval mlko.

This will work for other cases, including those without a preposition in Czech, even the nominative, and for questions:

+ Who knows the man who is sitting on the yellow sofa?
+ Intermediate: *Kter [mu] sed na lut pohovce?*
+ Kdo zn toho mue, kter sed na lut pohovce?

It may be easier for some students to recognize that the case of the pronoun is determined by the subordinate clause, and the gender/number by the element of the main clause to which the subordinate clause refers.

## Relative clause mid-sentence
The relative clause can be inserted in the middle of the main clause immediately following the element it refers to:

+ Dvku, u kter kad rno kupoval mlko, si vzal.
+ On/Frantiek si dvku, u kter kad rno kupoval mlko, vzal.

Note that the relative clause is needed to complete the unit of meaning, which is why in the first example the reflexive dative enclitic "si" must come immediately after it.

##Clitics in relative clauses
For keeping track of where the clitics should go, the form of "kter" with any associated preposition count as the first unit of meaning in the clause:

+ Pamatuje si tu studentku, kter jsme se ho bli dt? (Do you remember the student we were afraid to give him/it to?)

None of the clitics can climb up from the relative clause to the governing clause:

+ Pamatuje jsme si se ho tu studentku, kter bli dt?

skills.name: Movement
skills.tipsAndNotes:
#Verbs of motion
Czech verbs of motion exist in pairs that distinguish between **determinate** and **indeterminate** actions. This is not quite like the perfective vs imperfective distinction.

+ **Determinate** verbs of motion are used for single, one-directional, goal-directed movements.
+ **Indeterminate** verbs of motion are used for repeated, habitual, multi-directional, general (non-goal-directed) movements.

For example, compare these four common Czech verbs, all corresponding to English "go":

+ *jt* vs *chodit* (go, walk, go on foot)
+ *jet* vs *jezdit* (go, go by vehicle, ride)

The first verb in these pairs is determinate, the second indeterminate. Note also the distinction between **motion on foot** and **motion by vehicle**. Czech does not have a generic "go" like English.

##*Jt* (go, walk) 

| Number  | 1st person | 2nd person | 3rd person | 
|--|--|--|--|
| Sg. | jdu | jde | jde | 
| Pl. | jdeme | jdete | jdou |

In colloquial Czech the *j-* in these present forms is sometimes silent in pronunciation, similar to most of the present forms of *bt*. *J jsem.* and *Kam jde?* may sound like *J sem.* and *Kam de?*.  This does not happen in negative sentences.

The **past tense** forms of *jt* are *el* (m), *la* (f),  *lo* (n), *li/ly/la* (pl): *Ony ly dom.* (They went home.)

The **future tense** is created with the prefix *p-*: *Pjdu dom.* (I will go home.)

##*Jet* (go, ride, drive)

|  Number | 1st person | 2nd person | 3rd person | 
|--|--|--|--|
| Sg. | jedu | jede | jede | 
| Pl. | jedeme | jedete | jedou |

The **past tense** forms of *jet* are *jel* (m), *jela* (f), *jelo* (n), *jeli/jely/jela* (pl). *Kam jeli?* (Where did they go?)

The **future tense** is created with the prefix *po-*: *Pojedu dom.* (I will go home.)

##Notes

Note that *jt* and *jet* can also mean both "go" or "come", depending on the direction of travel:

+ *Jde/Jede sem.* (He is coming here.)
+ *Jde/Jede tam.* (He is going there.)

#Prefixed verbs of motion

The verbs of motion can also form aspectual pairs (imperfective and perfective) by prefixation, which alters their meanings.

*Od-* means "away", "from":

+ jt/chodit (go, walk)  become odejt/odchzet (go away, leave)
+ jet/jezdit (go, ride, drive)  become  odjet/odjdt (ride, go away, leave)

*Pi-* means "to", "near":

+ pijt/pichzet (arrive, come on foot) 
+ pijet/pijdt (arrive, come by vehicle)

skills.name: Dual
skills.tipsAndNotes:
This Skill introduces the names of several body parts. Pair body parts, like hands - *ruce*, legs - *nohy*, knees - *kolena*, shoulders - "ramena", eyes - *oi* and ears - *ui* follow a special type of declination in the plural. 

This declination is called dual because  it is derived from the Old Czech dual grammatical number, which was used instead of the plural number to all entities, if they happened to be in two. It is used for numbers *dva* (two) and *oba* (both) and then for certain (namely externally visible) body parts, even if there are more than two of them.

If some of these words are used in a derived meaning, like *nohy stolu* - the legs of a table, they use the regular plural declination, not the dual one.


| Case | Dual | Regular plural |
|--|--|--|
| nom. | nohy | nohy |
| gen. | nohou/noh | noh |
| dat. | nohm | nohm |
| loc. | nohou/nohch | nohch |
| instr.. | nohama | nohami |

Adjectives and numbers *ti* and *tyi* bound to dual nouns acquire dual endings as well: *zve se tyma velkma nohama* - an animal with four large legs

skills.name: Wishes
skills.tipsAndNotes:
# Wishes

Until these Tips & Notes are added, please refer to James Naughton's *Czech: An Essential Grammar*, section 7.9.1, pp. 153-154, and section 7.14.4, pp. 159-160.

skills.tipsAndNotes:

skills.name: Relative 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
# Relative clauses 2
In this skill we learn a few more relative pronouns to connect relative subordinate clauses to the main clause. So far we have been using the relative pronoun **"kter"**, which does the job of the English relative pronouns "who", "whom", "which", and "that". 

Recall that this Czech pronoun cannot be omitted and that there is no distinction between restrictive (defining) and non-restrictive (non-defining) use.

The example we studied in some detail was

+ Vzal si dvku, u kter kad rno kupoval mlko.

The case of the pronoun is determined by the subordinate clause, and the gender/number by the element of the main clause to which the subordinate clause refers.

##Relative pronoun "jen"
In formal contexts, the relative pronoun **"jen"** may be used instead of **"kter"**. This pronoun also comes in different forms for different genders and cases. The forms are challenging even for many native Czechs, but learning them could help our students decipher more formal texts.  

| Case/ Number | M an. | M in. | F | N |
|--|--|--|--|--|
| Nom. sg. | jen | jen | je | je |
| Acc. sg. | jeho, jej, nho, nj | jej, nj | ji, ni | je, n |
| Gen. sg. | jeho, jej, nho, nj | jeho, jej, nho, nj | j, n | jeho, jej, nho, nj |
| Loc. sg. | nm | nm | n | nm |
| Ins. sg. | jm, nm | jm, nm | j, n | jm, nm |
| Dat. sg. | jemu, nmu | jemu, nmu | j, n | jemu, nmu |
| Nom. pl. | ji | je | je | je |
| Acc. pl. | je, n | je, n | je, n | je, n |
| Gen. pl. | jich, nich | jich, nich | jich, nich | jich, nich |
| Loc. pl. | nich | nich | nich | nich |
| Ins. pl. | jimi, nimi | jimi, nimi | jimi, nimi | jimi, nimi |
| Dat. pl. | jim, nim | jim, nim | jim, nim | jim, nim |

As we have seen with personal pronouns, the forms starting with **j-** are used in the absence of a preposition, and those starting with **n-** are used after a preposition.

The connection with the personal pronouns will help us avoid the need to memorize the entire table. If we know which forms of the personal pronouns are used with which cases, we can simply append **-** to them. Using our milk girl from **Relative 1** again as an example, take the subordinate clause question:

+ U kter dvky kad rno kupoval mlko?

Replace what makes sense with the personal pronoun:

+ u **n** kad rno kupoval mlko

Append **-** to the pronoun and assemble the translation:

+ Vzal si dvku, u n kad rno kupoval mlko.

We do have to memorize the nominative forms, as we cannot just add **-** to "on" and get **"jen"**, to "oni" and get **"ji"**, or to the other nominative forms and get **"je"**.

##Relative clause mid-sentence
The relative clause can be inserted in the middle of the main clause immediately following the element it refers to:

+ Dvku, u n kad rno kupoval mlko, si vzal.
+ On/Frantiek si dvku, u n kad rno kupoval mlko, vzal.

Note that the relative clause is needed to complete the initial unit of meaning, which is why in the first example the reflexive dative enclitic "si" from the verb in the main clause must come immediately after it.

##Clitics inside relative clauses
For keeping track of where the clitics should go inside the relative clauses, the form of "kter" or "jen" with any associated preposition count as the first unit of meaning in the clause:

+ Pamatuje si tu studentku, kter/j jsme se ho bli dt? (Do you remember the student we were afraid to give him/it to?)

None of the clitics can "climb up" from the relative clause to the governing clause:

+ ???Pamatuje jsme si se ho tu studentku, kter/j bli dt?

skills.name: What The?!
skills.tipsAndNotes:
#What the?! Common Czech

See https://forum.duolingo.com/comment/35769759 for details and a warning.

Up to this point, the course was teaching standard Czech. Here we introduce common Czech, spoken in informal contexts pretty much by the entire native population of Bohemia and found in book and movie dialogue. 

Lets look at the main deviations of common Czech from the standard. 

###o -> vo (Von votevel vokno.)

Common Czech often inserts *v* in front of the word-initial *o*. Words like *okno*, *on*, *oba*, *otevt*, and *o* may become *vokno*, *von*, *voba*, *votevt* and *vo*.

###Plural Nom./Acc. and gender merger for demonstratives and hard adjectives (Ty americk turisti pili vo sv telefony.)

Sequences like *ti nov*, *ty nov*, and *ta nov* (the/those new) are simplified to one common form in Nom./Acc. and all genders. This also impacts other demonstratives (*tamten*, *tenhle*) and words that decline like hard adjectives (such as pronouns *jak*, *kter*,  and *mj*).

| Form | M an. | M in. | F | N |
| - | - | - | - | - |
| Nom. standard | ti nov | ty nov | ty nov | ta nov |
| Acc. standard | ty nov | ty nov | ty nov | ta nov |
| Nom./Acc. common | ty nov | ty nov | ty nov | ty nov |

The common hard adjective form also gets rid of the standard consonant shifts before the *-* ending. 

### ->  (Pro chce to velk zve ve svm malm pokoji?)

This shift is common in endings of hard adjectives and words that decline like them. 

### -> ej (Mluvil vo svejch novejch sousedech.)

This shift is common in endings of hard adjectives and words that decline like them but does not apply to the singular instrumental endings. We only shift the standard **, not the ** resulting from other common shifts.

###Dual endings in plural instrumental (Kam la s tma tema velkejma hrukama?)

In common Czech, the special *-a* endings in Pl. Ins. reserved in the standard for *ruce*, *nohy*, *oi*, and *ui* along with any associated adjectives, various pronouns including demonstratives, and cardinal numerals *ti* and *tyi* when referring to specific body parts of animate beings are used in Pl. Ins. without limitation to the listed nouns or animate being status. 

###Our new hard adjective declension table

The *highlighted* forms are non-standard:

| Num./Case | M an. | M in. | F | N
| - | - | - | - | -
| Sg. Nom. | nov*ej* | nov*ej* | nov | nov**
| Sg. Acc. | nov**ho | nov*ej* | novou | nov**
| Sg. Gen. | nov**ho | nov**ho | nov** | nov**ho
| Sg. Loc. | nov**m | nov**m | nov** | nov**m
| Sg. Ins. | novm | novm | novou | novm
| Sg. Dat. | nov**mu | nov**mu | novou | novm
| Pl. Nom./Acc. | nov** | nov** | nov** | nov**
| Pl. Gen./Loc. | nov*ej*ch | nov*ej*ch | nov*ej*ch |  nov*ej*ch
| Pl. Ins. | nov*ej*m*a* | nov*ej*m*a* | nov*ej*m*a* | nov*ej*m*a*
| Pl. Dat. | nov*ej*m | nov*ej*m | nov*ej*m | nov*ej*m

###Masculine plural locative hard noun ending -ch -> -ch (Pu knihy vo vlkch.)

The masculine plural locative ending *-ch* for hard declension nouns sometimes becomes *-ch*, and the consonant shift of the standard is avoided.

###Deletion of the final -l in the past-tense verb form (Kdo ti to ek?)

The final *-l* following a consonant in the past-tense verb form is often deleted.

###Unified ending in the plural past-tense verb form across all genders (Stli tam ty auta.)

The "common" plural past-tense ending is *-li* regardless of gender.

###Verb ending -eme -> -em (My vodejdem.)

The plural first person verb ending *-eme* may become just *-em*. 

###Deletion of j from some verb forms (J tam nepudu, sou tam voni.)

Forms like *(p)jdu* and *(p)jde* often become *(pu)du* and *(pu)de*. The unprefixed negatives like *nejdu* remain unchanged.

*Pjit* and its forms can also undergo the transformation from *j* to *u*. 

The forms *jsem*, *jsi* (*jse*), *jsme*, *jste*, and *jsou* often lose the initial *j-*. The negative forms like *nejsem* remain unchanged. The forms *jse* and *nejse* are other possible common versions of *jsi* and *nejsi*.

###Auxiliary/conjunction ending -chom -> -sme (Kdybysme mohli, tak bysme vodeli.)

The plural first person auxiliary/conjunctions *bychom*, *abychom*, and *kdybychom* often become *(a/kdy)bysme*. 

###Plural 3rd person verb endings -aj/-ej/-j  -> -aj/-ej/-j (kaj, e to nechtj.)

These plural third-person endings sometimes lose the final *-*. 

###Plural 3rd person verb ending - -> -ej/-j (Nevdj to.)

The plural third-person verb ending *-* following a consonant other than j sometimes morphs to *-ej*/*-j*. 

###Simplified singular possessive adjectives (V ofiin kole)

These mirror hard adjectives.

###Distorted and new words

A few examples of the changed or expanded vocabulary are introduced: *bark* (*dm*), *bejt*, *brcha* (*bratr*), *furt* (*pod*), *k* (*njak*), *prachy* (*penze*), *rychlejc* (*rychleji*), *tyry*, *tejden*, *tendle* (*tenhle*), *vim*, *vidim*, and *zejtra*.
